I missed Dragon Kart, but, it was sorta janky in the first place and Kasuga being in Sonic Racing really makes Dragon Kart look that much more janky.

The new characters are great as well, Tomi, Yamai, Chitose - all great and well developed with their own unique sources of intrigue. Kasuga is just such a lovable idiot, and a bad ass of course, but he's just got so much heart, and it's another excellent example of that.

[spoiler] The way they deal with Kiryu's send-off is really great. Having all those memories to revisit and have him reflect on, or in some cases, get closure on, those things and characters from the series was very rewarding having gone through the series this year, and among my favourite parts of this game. About 10 years ago I jumped into the Yakuza/Like a Dragon series. I was a lot later on it than some people, but I have really loved the mainline series of these games. The first 7 games (counting from Yakuza 0) were all action/beat 'em ups. They were great, they were fun, but the style was maybe starting to wear a tad thin. Once we got to Yakuza Like a Dragon, not only did they change the protagonist, but they changed the style. It became a JRPG in the vein of a Dragon Quest. I loved it even more. 

I was extremely excited to continue on the story from the last game, and while I enjoyed Infinite Wealth... It wasn't without some serious faults. The battle system does just enough that it isn't a static turned based system (which I have no problem with turn based games. I love them). The characters are endearing, the story is solid (although that is where the majority of my issues come from). I didn't walk away 100% satisfied once the credits rolled. Which was not how I felt after any of the previous games in the series. There was a little bit of a hollow feeling. 

It's not my favorite of the series, and it's not the worst game in the series. It's closer to middle of the pack, which is a shame because it had a chance to be really special. The story pacing and how it developed was not up to par. Things felt a little rushed as you reached the end game, but at times it dragged on for too long in places earlier on. It was very uneven. Additionally, there were some performance issues and freezes. Sometimes the game would just crash. Make sure you save often. It was playable on the Steam Deck, though my definition of playable may differ from others. Don't expect amazing visuals or high FPS. But in an RPG, it was acceptable. And it's nice to be able to pick up and play longer games like this without being tethered to your desk.

I still think it's worth playing and experiencing if you enjoyed the main protagonists from either the Yakuza games or Like a Dragon. It's best if you have played the other mainline games (And Like a Dragon Gaiden) but that is quite a time commitment. It's an interesting one, I just wish it had done a better job story-wise.

negative.review: Infinite Wealth starts out with great gameplay that by the end becomes exhausting and absurdly boring, the story has an interesting premise that completely drops in writing quality halfway through the game and just keeps getting worse the more you play. The antagonists in Infinite Wealth are by far the worst in the entire franchise.

Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth is a turn-based RPG with a dozen other games included, and it's a good and decent experience that I found deeply derivative and unsatisfying. It is a high-quality game with a lot to enjoy, so my thumbs down is just a couple of degrees below the horizon line.

I think you should only play this after playing Like a Dragon, which was a good starting point for the series. Gameplay-wise it's similar, but better overall. I enjoyed a lot of mini-games, and a lot of effort was spent on making many of the substories unique in some way, having a special mini-game or interesting boss battle. The main dish - tactical combat, JRPG style - is also fine, but that's where I start to complain, and I don't think I'll stop complaining until the end. The game has no difficulty selection (at least for the first playthrough) and if you engage with any side content you become overpowered fast, which means that the main gameplay mode - tactical combat - becomes just a chore. And side content was what I actually liked in this game, so the critical path quickly became boring. All of the tools available to you are mostly pointles there's a fun job-switching system, but there isn't much point in engaging with it unless you want to do the post-game extra-difficult dungeon. There's crafting and optional randomized dungeon clearing - and I enjoyed those, there you see glimpses of how this combat system can be used, but it again makes you overpowered. So pacing and balancing are way off.

What remains is a story. I can't call it bad, but the thing is usually in this series the story is exceptional. It is simultaneously the most serious dramatic thing you've ever seen and also the silliest thing you've ever seen. And this one is more conventional, it's tongue-in-cheek, it knows that it's too dramatic and too silly from time to time. It doesn't feel sincere. On top of it, a lot of it is tone-deaf. The plight of little people is one of the big themes of the game, but the two biggest side activities in the game are a Pokémon-style fighting game where you force homeless and crazy people to fight for food, and a resort management game where the same homeless and crazy people are used as unpaid labor. It's played for laughs and I don't condemn the game for having those activities, but I personally couldn't enjoy them. Gameplay-wise they felt out of place too: the Pokémon game is a separate turn-based tactical combat mini-game and we already had one; the resort management game interrupts the normal game and is almost completely separate from it. You can play it for hours and forget how to play the main game, ha. The story is also very derivative. It feels like half of the side stories concern characters you've met in the previous game, and for the second protagonist most of what they do is reviewing references to previous games. I played these games and found this boring, I imagine if you haven't played Yakuza 0-6 you'll be confused on top of being bored. I can't say it's an "objectively" wrong way to write a story, or even that it's poorly written, but it feels the least unique and engaging entry in the franchise.

So here we are. I spent a lot of time on this game, and it wasn't that bad, but I mostly continued playing because I am committed to the series. If you want to skip one game in the franchise - skip this one.

Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth is a turn-based RPG with a dozen other games included, and it's a good and decent experience that I found deeply derivative and unsatisfying. It is a high-quality game with a lot to enjoy, so my thumbs down is just a couple of degrees below the horizon line.

I think you should only play this after playing Like a Dragon, which was a good starting point for the series. Gameplay-wise it's similar, but better overall. I enjoyed a lot of mini-games, and a lot of effort was spent on making many of the substories unique in some way, having a special mini-game or interesting boss battle. The main dish - tactical combat, JRPG style - is also fine, but that's where I start to complain, and I don't think I'll stop complaining until the end. The game has no difficulty selection (at least for the first playthrough) and if you engage with any side content you become overpowered fast, which means that the main gameplay mode - tactical combat - becomes just a chore. And side content was what I actually liked in this game, so the critical path quickly became boring. All of the tools available to you are mostly pointles there's a fun job-switching system, but there isn't much point in engaging with it unless you want to do the post-game extra-difficult dungeon. There's crafting and optional randomized dungeon clearing - and I enjoyed those, there you see glimpses of how this combat system can be used, but it again makes you overpowered. So pacing and balancing are way off.

What remains is a story. I can't call it bad, but the thing is usually in this series the story is exceptional. It is simultaneously the most serious dramatic thing you've ever seen and also the silliest thing you've ever seen. And this one is more conventional, it's tongue-in-cheek, it knows that it's too dramatic and too silly from time to time. It doesn't feel sincere. On top of it, a lot of it is tone-deaf. The plight of little people is one of the big themes of the game, but the two biggest side activities in the game are a Pokémon-style fighting game where you force homeless and crazy people to fight for food, and a resort management game where the same homeless and crazy people are used as unpaid labor. It's played for laughs and I don't condemn the game for having those activities, but I personally couldn't enjoy them. Gameplay-wise they felt out of place too: the Pokémon game is a separate turn-based tactical combat mini-game and we already had one; the resort management game interrupts the normal game and is almost completely separate from it. You can play it for hours and forget how to play the main game, ha. The story is also very derivative. It feels like half of the side stories concern characters you've met in the previous game, and for the second protagonist most of what they do is reviewing references to previous games. I played these games and found this boring, I imagine if you haven't played Yakuza 0-6 you'll be confused on top of being bored. I can't say it's an "objectively" wrong way to write a story, or even that it's poorly written, but it feels the least unique and engaging entry in the franchise.

So here we are. I spent a lot of time on this game, and it wasn't that bad, but I mostly continued playing because I am committed to the series. If you want to skip one game in the franchise - skip this one.

I love the Like a Dragon franchise, but the games with Kasuga as a protagonist simply don't cut it.

Now the Prologue of the game was fucking amazing. So well executed. With criticism against Japans harsh Anti-Yakuza-Laws. Then the very moment they go this stupid "Kasuga is a hero like in a game!"-route again it all crumbles down in an instant.

First: The whole Reboot thing doesn't work. This game here is literally a continuation of Kiryus Story which started with Yakuza 1 back in the days. Heck. Even the final achievement makes this very clear. You really need to have played every game to understand what is going on.

They crammed Kasuga in here with his whole "Looking for my mother!"-story. But this part is so irrelevant. Because everything would've happened without him anyways. He feels like a side character.

Not that the story is worth much anyways. The game just goes in circles for around 8 chapters, making you slog through a ton of lengthy minigame explanations. Then one or teo interesting things happen. Thennit's more time wasting until the ending cutscene which was rather nice again.

Speaking of cutscenes. I loved the franchise for them. But in this game they are mostly just "Everybody standing around while somebody has a 20 minute exposition dialogue"

Now if only the gameplay would hold up. But it does not. Hawaii with its palm trees is a nice setting. There are some cool new characters. And the battles can be fun to watch for a bit. But that's it.

The downsides are that this is a turn based battle system where positioning of characters is important ... but you can barely influence their position. Everybody is just randomly walking around. Enemies tend to move out of your AoE. And its also important to push enemies into other enemies or your allies for extra damage ... but often you miss that despite specifically aligning everything with the arrows the game displays.

And then enemies actually have death protection. Sometimes you would do enough damage ... the game just says: Nope! Wait until next round. Another hit please!

It's not that this makes it hard. Just annoying. It's stretching game time. And it's especially annoying as you often encounter enemy groups with 8 people and you always have to wait for all of them to make their attack befoee it's your turn. In the worst scenarios this leads to situations where you win one battle, get sent to the next and then get a game over as you can't do anything but watching how your team gets pummeled.

This franchise was never made with turn based battles in mind and it shows. This game often seems to cry "Let me be real time!" with Kiryus attack which actually lets you fight a few seconds real time again.

And on top of this where is still the problem of tone: These over the top silly enemies simply don't fit a story about revenge and social criticism. One second you fight oversized people using a pizza as a shield and eating it to heal, then you are supposed to take a scene serious where a guy gets cut open.

Then the new map is barely used. It felt like there were exactly 2 points on the map. Because for every new main mission you had to run from one end to the other and then back again. Sometimes not even for a real reason but "We should rest a bit!" Despite easily available quick travel that felt really lazy.

If they hadn't included the old characters I would've skipped it. Now's just hoping that this is really the end of the old cast, so I can skip any new games they make about Kasuga. At least some of the good parts like Hawaii are reused in Gaiden 2.

Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth is a turn-based RPG with a dozen other games included, and it's a good and decent experience that I found deeply derivative and unsatisfying. It is a high-quality game with a lot to enjoy, so my thumbs down is just a couple of degrees below the horizon line.

I think you should only play this after playing Like a Dragon, which was a good starting point for the series. Gameplay-wise it's similar, but better overall. I enjoyed a lot of mini-games, and a lot of effort was spent on making many of the substories unique in some way, having a special mini-game or interesting boss battle. The main dish - tactical combat, JRPG style - is also fine, but that's where I start to complain, and I don't think I'll stop complaining until the end. The game has no difficulty selection (at least for the first playthrough) and if you engage with any side content you become overpowered fast, which means that the main gameplay mode - tactical combat - becomes just a chore. And side content was what I actually liked in this game, so the critical path quickly became boring. All of the tools available to you are mostly pointles there's a fun job-switching system, but there isn't much point in engaging with it unless you want to do the post-game extra-difficult dungeon. There's crafting and optional randomized dungeon clearing - and I enjoyed those, there you see glimpses of how this combat system can be used, but it again makes you overpowered. So pacing and balancing are way off.

What remains is a story. I can't call it bad, but the thing is usually in this series the story is exceptional. It is simultaneously the most serious dramatic thing you've ever seen and also the silliest thing you've ever seen. And this one is more conventional, it's tongue-in-cheek, it knows that it's too dramatic and too silly from time to time. It doesn't feel sincere. On top of it, a lot of it is tone-deaf. The plight of little people is one of the big themes of the game, but the two biggest side activities in the game are a Pokémon-style fighting game where you force homeless and crazy people to fight for food, and a resort management game where the same homeless and crazy people are used as unpaid labor. It's played for laughs and I don't condemn the game for having those activities, but I personally couldn't enjoy them. Gameplay-wise they felt out of place too: the Pokémon game is a separate turn-based tactical combat mini-game and we already had one; the resort management game interrupts the normal game and is almost completely separate from it. You can play it for hours and forget how to play the main game, ha. The story is also very derivative. I love the Like a Dragon franchise, but the games with Kasuga as a protagonist simply don't cut it.

Now the Prologue of the game was fucking amazing. So well executed. With criticism against Japans harsh Anti-Yakuza-Laws. Then the very moment they go this stupid "Kasuga is a hero like in a game!"-route again it all crumbles down in an instant.

First: The whole Reboot thing doesn't work. This game here is literally a continuation of Kiryus Story which started with Yakuza 1 back in the days. Heck. Even the final achievement makes this very clear. You really need to have played every game to understand what is going on.

They crammed Kasuga in here with his whole "Looking for my mother!"-story. But this part is so irrelevant. Because everything would've happened without him anyways. He feels like a side character.

Not that the story is worth much anyways. The game just goes in circles for around 8 chapters, making you slog through a ton of lengthy minigame explanations. Then one or teo interesting things happen. Thennit's more time wasting until the ending cutscene which was rather nice again.

Speaking of cutscenes. I loved the franchise for them. But in this game they are mostly just "Everybody standing around while somebody has a 20 minute exposition dialogue"

Now if only the gameplay would hold up. But it does not. Hawaii with its palm trees is a nice setting. There are some cool new characters. And the battles can be fun to watch for a bit. But that's it.

The downsides are that this is a turn based battle system where positioning of characters is important ... but you can barely influence their position. Everybody is just randomly walking around. Enemies tend to move out of your AoE. And its also important to push enemies into other enemies or your allies for extra damage ... but often you miss that despite specifically aligning everything with the arrows the game displays.

And then enemies actually have death protection. Sometimes you would do enough damage ... the game just says: Nope! Wait until next round. Another hit please!

It's not that this makes it hard. Just annoying. It's stretching game time. And it's especially annoying as you often encounter enemy groups with 8 people and you always have to wait for all of them to make their attack befoee it's your turn. In the worst scenarios this leads to situations where you win one battle, get sent to the next and then get a game over as you can't do anything but watching how your team gets pummeled.

This franchise was never made with turn based battles in mind and it shows. This game often seems to cry "Let me be real time!" with Kiryus attack which actually lets you fight a few seconds real time again.

And on top of this where is still the problem of tone: These over the top silly enemies simply don't fit a story about revenge and social criticism. One second you fight oversized people using a pizza as a shield and eating it to heal, then you are supposed to take a scene serious where a guy gets cut open.

Then the new map is barely used. It felt like there were exactly 2 points on the map. Because for every new main mission you had to run from one end to the other and then back again. Sometimes not even for a real reason but "We should rest a bit!" Despite easily available quick travel that felt really lazy.

If they hadn't included the old characters I would've skipped it. Now's just hoping that this is really the end of the old cast, so I can skip any new games they make about Kasuga. At least some of the good parts like Hawaii are reused in Gaiden 2.

Like a Dragon: Infinite Wealth is a turn-based RPG with a dozen other games included, and it's a good and decent experience that I found deeply derivative and unsatisfying. It is a high-quality game with a lot to enjoy, so my thumbs down is just a couple of degrees below the horizon line.

I think you should only play this after playing Like a Dragon, which was a good starting point for the series. Gameplay-wise it's similar, but better overall. I enjoyed a lot of mini-games, and a lot of effort was spent on making many of the substories unique in some way, having a special mini-game or interesting boss battle. The main dish - tactical combat, JRPG style - is also fine, but that's where I start to complain, and I don't think I'll stop complaining until the end. The game has no difficulty selection (at least for the first playthrough) and if you engage with any side content you become overpowered fast, which means that the main gameplay mode - tactical combat - becomes just a chore. And side content was what I actually liked in this game, so the critical path quickly became boring. All of the tools available to you are mostly pointles there's a fun job-switching system, but there isn't much point in engaging with it unless you want to do the post-game extra-difficult dungeon. There's crafting and optional randomized dungeon clearing - and I enjoyed those, there you see glimpses of how this combat system can be used, but it again makes you overpowered. So pacing and balancing are way off.

What remains is a story. I can't call it bad, but the thing is usually in this series the story is exceptional. It is simultaneously the most serious dramatic thing you've ever seen and also the silliest thing you've ever seen. And this one is more conventional, it's tongue-in-cheek, it knows that it's too dramatic and too silly from time to time. It doesn't feel sincere. On top of it, a lot of it is tone-deaf. The plight of little people is one of the big themes of the game, but the two biggest side activities in the game are a Pokémon-style fighting game where you force homeless and crazy people to fight for food, and a resort management game where the same homeless and crazy people are used as unpaid labor. It's played for laughs and I don't condemn the game for having those activities, but I personally couldn't enjoy them. Gameplay-wise they felt out of place too: the Pokémon game is a separate turn-based tactical combat mini-game and we already had one; the resort management game interrupts the normal game and is almost completely separate from it. You can play it for hours and forget how to play the main game, ha. The story is also very derivative. It feels like half of the side stories concern characters you've met in the previous game, and for the second protagonist most of what they do is reviewing references to previous games. I played these games and found this boring, I imagine if you haven't played Yakuza 0-6 you'll be confused on top of being bored. I can't say it's an "objectively" wrong way to write a story, or even that it's poorly written, but it feels the least unique and engaging entry in the franchise.

So here we are. I spent a lot of time on this game, and it wasn't that bad, but I mostly continued playing because I am committed to the series. If you want to skip one game in the franchise - skip this one.

I love the Like a Dragon franchise, but the games with Kasuga as a protagonist simply don't cut it.

Now the Prologue of the game was fucking amazing. So well executed. With criticism against Japans harsh Anti-Yakuza-Laws. Then the very moment they go this stupid "Kasuga is a hero like in a game!"-route again it all crumbles down in an instant.

First: The whole Reboot thing doesn't work. This game here is literally a continuation of Kiryus Story which started with Yakuza 1 back in the days. Heck. Even the final achievement makes this very clear. You really need to have played every game to understand what is going on.

They crammed Kasuga in here with his whole "Looking for my mother!"-story. But this part is so irrelevant. Because everything would've happened without him anyways. He feels like a side character.

Not that the story is worth much anyways. The game just goes in circles for around 8 chapters, making you slog through a ton of lengthy minigame explanations. Then one or teo interesting things happen. Thennit's more time wasting until the ending cutscene which was rather nice again.

Speaking of cutscenes. I loved the franchise for them. But in this game they are mostly just "Everybody standing around while somebody has a 20 minute exposition dialogue"

Now if only the gameplay would hold up. But it does not. Hawaii with its palm trees is a nice setting. There are some cool new characters. And the battles can be fun to watch for a bit. But that's it.

The downsides are that this is a turn based battle system where positioning of characters is important ... but you can barely influence their position. Everybody is just randomly walking around. Enemies tend to move out of your AoE. And its also important to push enemies into other enemies or your allies for extra damage ... but often you miss that despite specifically aligning everything with the arrows the game displays.

And then enemies actually have death protection. Sometimes you would do enough damage ... the game just says: Nope! Wait until next round. Another hit please!

It's not that this makes it hard. Just annoying. It's stretching game time. And it's especially annoying as you often encounter enemy groups with 8 people and you always have to wait for all of them to make their attack befoee it's your turn. In the worst scenarios this leads to situations where you win one battle, get sent to the next and then get a game over as you can't do anything but watching how your team gets pummeled.

This franchise was never made with turn based battles in mind and it shows. This game often seems to cry "Let me be real time!" with Kiryus attack which actually lets you fight a few seconds real time again.

And on top of this where is still the problem of tone: These over the top silly enemies simply don't fit a story about revenge and social criticism. One second you fight oversized people using a pizza as a shield and eating it to heal, then you are supposed to take a scene serious where a guy gets cut open.

Then the new map is barely used. It felt like there were exactly 2 points on the map. Because for every new main mission you had to run from one end to the other and then back again. Sometimes not even for a real reason but "We should rest a bit!" Despite easily available quick travel that felt really lazy.

If they hadn't included the old characters I would've skipped it. Now's just hoping that this is really the end of the old cast, so I can skip any new games they make about Kasuga. At least some of the good parts like Hawaii are reused in Gaiden 2.

I'm just happy that I got this on a good sale and didn't pay full price.

There are no orphanages in America.  The legal structure for it just doesn't exist.  There might be edge cases of foster parents grossly abusing the program but the concept of a structured orphanage just has not existed in America for decades.  The type of foster situation depicted would put the people at the top all over the media!  Never even minding the bizarre cult that comes off as crass parody, which does all this and also miraculously protects the identity of the McGuffin, the plot doesn't make ANY sense.  Why set your plot outside of Japan if you are just going to make pretend it's Japan??  It's not just the orphanage, it's cultural stuff all over the place.  The writing is filtered through a prism that distorts way too much for anything coherent to emerge.

e - the more I think about it, the dumber it gets.  so many natural born and raised English speakers are just primed and ready to speak fluent Japanese and bow/respect with perfect mannerisms at any Asian looking person.  except when these people speak in English, which they always contextually know when to do, and depending on the budget for the character can range from distracting and thick accented English to native competency but Fiverr delivery.  I played with Japanese audio and out of empathy for my fellow man I refuse to imagine the nightmare the English voice director probably went through trying to interpret the intention.

There's a whole lot one could say about the treatment of Ichiban as a foreign national "without an identity" but I suppose if you just wanted to get over it you could chalk all of that up to commentary on the universal treatment of police on the vulnerable, and yes, American prejudice.  However, you just can't terminate the thought there like the writing wants you to.  The way the story draws out its painful legal arguments to Ichiban's predicaments makes you realize the writers don't actually have a clue what would happen.

Rereading this makes me realize all of this applies to Chitose just as fairly, though at least in her case the emotional confusion itself is much more fundamental to her story.  There are other gross obvious problems with her story that actually have nothing to do with the immigrant tale but let's hold on to an emotional hook where we can get it.  I guess after my 35 hrs I find Kiyru's story the most credible overall but there's almost nothing to it at the point I gave up so maybe I didn't give them time to cook and make something awful.

Language and cultural barriers are intimate and significant to Ichiban's fish out of water with the exception of when translating across boundaries is just too hard.  Lame, and ill advised.  This becomes especially obnoxious when there is so much tedious dialog that adds nothing where that kind of tedium would have semantically made sense in other places.

e - gameplay is fine.
